property.name: ipa_domain
property.description: Domain name to be used by FreeIPA. Kerberos realm and ldap realm are derived from this value. Please choose a domain wisely, see https://www.freeipa.org/page/DNS#Caveats.

property.name: client_init_wait
property.description: The time in seconds the client installation process will wait for a admin password file.

property.name: forwarders
property.description: The IP address of the DNS server to whom FreeIPA should first forward requests. Usually this is specific to your datacenter. This can be a comma-separated list.

property.name: directory_password
property.description: The directory_password will also be the ldap admin password. Must be at least 8 characters long. This parameter will be used during the initial installation. After the installation reconfiguration of this password will not have any effect.

property.name: ldap_bind_password
property.description:
The password of the user created for binding services through LDAP. Must be at least 8 characters long. This setting is not automatically picked up by the services which would want to bind. This only used to generate this specific user. Be sure to set ipa_integration_enabled to True on the service you want to integrate and the ipa_bind_password to the same value as provided here.
If this setting is not set the give user is not generated during installation. If you at a later stage still want this option you'll have to go through the ipa interface to generate itself. This setting will not be interpreted twice.

property.name: initial_users_and_groups
property.description: Json description of intial users to add to FreeIPA, along with any groups. If these users and groups already exist, nothing is done. you can use the simple format: e.g.: {"Users" : ["bob","eve"], "Groups" : { "gitlab" : ["bob"], "scientists" : ["eve", "bob"], "admins" : ["bob"] } } of the extended format: e.g.: {"Users" : [{ "username" : "bob", "email":"bob@bob.bob", "firstname":"Robert", "lastname":"Jones"},{"username": "eve"}], "Groups" : [ {"name":"gitlab", "members" : ["bob"]},{"name":"admins", "members" : ["bob"]}] } If you want to make some special admin users, you should add them here. By default random passwords are assigned which must be changed on first login. If you want to specify the passwords yourself then add a password to the initial_user_password field.

property.name: initial_user_passwords
property.description: Json description of intial passwords to set in freeIPA. This is only used if a new user is added. e.g.: {"bob":"mynameisbobandIamanadminandthisisnotmypassword"} All passwords set this way must be at least eight characters. If set this way, passwords must be changed on the first login of this user.

property.name: initial_sudoers
property.description: List of usernames and groups to add to sudoers list. We automatically create the sudoer rule by the name of allsudo Making users sudoers allows them full privilages on the machines in the cluster 'Users': list of users to add 'Groups': list of groups to add Remaining options (cmdcat, hostcat, runasusercat, runasgroupcat) are the command-line args used when making the sudoers group see ipa sudorule-add --help for details, or the freeipa documentation online

property.name: install_with_dns
property.description: This will install the FreeIPA server with a DNS. This will also overwrite some dns related network settings. PLEASE NOTE! The network settings are NOT permanently overwriten. this is the machine owners responsibility. The install without dns is not the recommended way to go, but this is up to you and your network admin. It is a great feature of FreeIPA that it can also control an internal DNS, but sometimes this can conflict with setting of your network.

property.name: default_shell
property.description: Default shell for all users, if you intend to use KaveToolbox, this should be set to /bin/bash.

property.name: ldap_bind_user
property.description: The name of the user created for binding services through LDAP. This setting is not automatically picked up by the services which would want to bind. This only used to generate this specific user. Be sure to set ipa_integration_enabled to True on the service you want to integrate and the ipa_bind_user to the same value as provided here.

property.name: kadm5acl_template
property.value: */admin@{{realm}} * admin@{{realm}} * admin@{{realm}} a * admin@{{realm}} i * admin@{{realm}} x * admin@{{realm}} m *
property.description: The kadm5.acl file controls who can modify the kerberos database directly. This is usually just the explicit kerberos admin.

property.name: resolvconf_template
property.description: Rasolve.conf is needed within the cluster to locate machines. An advanced user will want to modify this in case they have multiple internal domains.

property.name: searchpath
property.description: Java installation locations where JCE needs to be installed. This is required for kerberizing the cluster using freeIPA With the default this will look in common installation directories for both openjdk and oraclejdk on centos7

property.name: folderpath
property.description: Folder location for Java Cryptographic Extension jar files need to be placed

property.name: admin_user_shell
property.description: For the two administrators we create, 'admin' and 'robot-admin' we don't want to create these as system-level shell users, and so we set their shells to /sbin/nologin by default. To restore old behaviour modify this, or kinit as an admin user and call ipa user-mod --shell on the command line.

property.name: install_distribution_user
property.description: User to distribute the robot-admin password file to the client; this is required to be 'cloudbreak' on Cloudbreak, otherwise it may be safely left to 'root'. In any case, an identity private key with the standard name 'id_rsa' and the right permission and ownership is expected in the .ssh directory of this user - on Cloudbreak you would accomplish this with a pre-recipe.
